awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Accelerated Development of Damage Tolerant and Oxidation Resistant Alumina-Forming MAX Phases
awd_abstract_narration:
Materials capable of withstanding harsh environments have the potential to enable a wide range of important technologies.  A family of ceramic carbide and nitride materials referred to as MAX phases possess unusual and often unique sets of properties that combine some of the best attributes of ceramics and metals. These are light, stiff, stable and able to resist high temperatures like typical ceramics, but also damage tolerant, ductile at high temperatures and as readily machinable as metals. In addition, some of the MAX phases form protective layers when heated in air, that are extremely resistant to thermal shock, thermal cycling and chemical attack. This Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) award supports fundamental research to understand the process by which these protective layers in MAX phases are formed. This research will incorporate  computational simulations and experimental synthesis and characterization to build the knowledge base for the accelerated development and design of MAX phase materials with outstanding mechanical properties for high temperature applications. Results of this project will foster application of MAX phases in power generation, energy conversion, transportation, aerospace and defense technologies. This project also provides specialized multidisciplinary training for graduate and undergraduate students on integrating materials informatics, modeling, atomistic computations and experiments in materials design.

Despite two decades of experimental studies on MAX phases, designing their optimal composition and microstructure has remained a challenge mainly because of the large number of possible compositions and microstructures, and a lack of robust physical models that relate their composition and microstructure to properties. The overall goal of this research program is to overcome those challenges and foster design of MAX phases for high temperature applications by: (1) developing physics-based predictors for the formation of protective alumina layers; (2) developing micromechanical models and identifying compositional/structural parameters that control intrinsic thermomechanical properties; (3) designing Bayesian calibration protocols for parameter identification; (4) implementing and deploying Efficient Global Optimization protocols for the efficient discovery of MAX phases with optimal thermomechanical properties and; (5) validating the proposed framework through material synthesis, characterization and thermomechanical testing. This will provide guiding fundamental knowledge and protocols to design optimal compositions and microstructures of the MAX phases for high temperature application.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
At high temperatures most metallic alloys will either melt or turn to their oxides and this limits their high temperature applications such as jet engines, hypersonic and airspace vehicles, and power generation. To solve this problem material scientists have come up with various solutions. One of the most successful is to introduce/alloy aluminum, Al in the metal. If the Al concentration is high enough, at high temperature, it will diffuse to the surface and react with oxygen and form a protective Al-oxide layer (see Fig. 1). If the layer that forms is adhesive and thin enough it protects the underlying alloy or compound by greatly reducing the rate of oxidation. In addition, most of metallic alloys, if heated to high enough temperatures, will lose all their strengths; they become putty-like before they melt. Thus, another important characteristic of a material to possess for high temperature applications is that it remains strong at high temperatures and does not deform and fail under applied loads with time. Thus, for a material to be used as load bearing at high temperatures it must be both oxidation and creep resistant.

Despite decades of research the number of materials and alloys that form Al-oxide and are good enough for high temperature applications are few and far between. In 1996 on of PIs of this proposal discovered a new class of ceramics that were unlike any discovered before. These ceramics, labelled the MAX phases because of their chemical composition, are fully machinable and some of them form Al-oxide protective layers when heated in air at high temperatures. In addition, their damage tolerance is exceptional when compared to other otherwise brittle ceramic materials. Despite two decades of experimental primarily studies suggesting that this class of materials has outstanding potential for applications at high temperatures, designing their optimal, composition and microstructure for their outstanding oxidation resistance and mechanical properties remains a challenge, mainly because the composition space is quite large and because we lack accurate computational models to supplement experiments. The overall goal of this collaborative research program between Texas A&M University and Drexel University was to overcome those challenges by integrating advanced experimental synthesis and characterization with artificial intelligence, AI, to guide the discovery of new MAX phase compositions that are oxidation and creep resistant.

Intellectual Merits:  The following notable advances were made in this work: (1) discovered a potentially revolutionary approach to estimate the oxidation behavior of any compositionally complex solid phase. The method combines atomic models, AI and thermodynamics to predict the stability of solid materials against oxidation at elevated temperatures. This method is at least seven orders of magnitude faster than previous approached and potentially extend to materials beyond MAX phases; (2) developed new experimental technique that allows for accelerated screening of oxidation that only takes several hours, instead of testing many samples for hundreds of hours. This method was used to experimentally verify computational prediction of oxidation stability for Ti2AlC, Cr2AlC MAX phases; (3) showed that exceptional damage tolerance of MAX phases can be partially attributed to crack healing even at room temperature; (5) discovered two MAX phases that form a protective Al-oxide layer; (6) demonstrated that the composition of the A-layer can be tuned to enhance the creep resistance opening the door to enhancing creep resistance.

Broader Impacts: From a technological point of view, the results of this project will foster discovery of not only novel MAX phases - but also other multicomponent materials - for use at high-temperatures, including efficient energy conversion and generation, aerospace, transportation and defense. Results of this project have been reported in 31 peer reviewed journal publications and a number of invited talks and conference presentations. This work also positively impacted graduate and undergraduate student trainees, K-12 students, and the general public. Six PhD students (5 graduated in last 5 years and one finishing up). Five undergraduate students from Texas A&M University were mentored, including 2 minority students. At Drexel, the graduate students participate in a full day, free event (Materials Day) open to all audiences highlighting what materials are and their crucial role in society. The team also developed instructive demonstration on mechanical properties of ceramics for K-12 students and general public and participated in the Spring Camp at the Brazos Valley Museum of Natural History, Texas A&M Physic and Engineering Festival, etc. Last but not least, the PI co-curated exhibit  “Fire and Earth: The Story of Ceramics” at the Brazos Valley Museum of Natural History in Bryan, Texas, where some of the MAX phase materials developed through this project were presented.

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2023
Modified by: Miladin Radovic

Image

    Michel Barsoum, Drexel University

    Miladin Radovic
    Alumina Oxide Scale
